headline: Deutsche Telekom Statement on Decision
summary: Deutsche Telekom Statement on Decision

headline: No Headline Available
summary: The Journal analyzed the tracking files installed by the 50 most popular websites and built an index of visitors' exposure to monitoring. See.

headline: Jones Day Letter
summary: Jones Day Letter

headline: End of the Road for Saab
summary: Saab Automobile, the Swedish auto maker, which filed for bankruptcy after a desperate three-year fight for survival, will be missed as a once-innovative manufacturer of turbo-charged cars.

headline: Vintage Car Rally
summary: A vintage car rally took place in Delhi on Sunday. Some snapshots.

headline: The Life of a Dictator
summary: The son of North Korea's founder, Kim Jong Il ruled the reclusive country for nearly two decades.

summary: Pepper...and Salt for the week of December 19—December 24, 2011.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Dec. 19, 2011

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for Dec. 19, 2011

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Dec. 19

headline: Asia in Pictures
summary: Slum dwellers warm themselves by a fire in India, people mourn the death of Kim Jong Il in North Korea, flood victims try to recover a car washed away by floods in the Philippines, and more.

headline: Floods Devastate Southern Philippines
summary: More than 650 people were killed by flash floods caused by a tropical storm in southern Philippines. Two coastal cities turned into a muddy wasteland filled with overturned cars and uprooted trees.

headline: Stocks End on a Low Note
summary: Banks led U.S. stocks lower, sagging under the weight of another batch of worrisome headlines from Europe and fresh expectations for tighter capital standards.

headline: Shell Reports Gulf Drilling Spill
summary: Shell said it had temporarily abandoned a deepwater well in the Gulf of Mexico after it spilled 319 barrels of fluid used to drill the well.

headline: Clashes Leave 10 Dead in Cairo
summary: Protesters and Egyptian military forces threw rocks at one another in Cairo as clashes left at least 10 people dead and more than 400 wounded. The military regime is under pressure ahead of its handover of power to civilian rule. (Reuters)

headline: Egypt Violence Extends Into Third Day
summary: Fighting between military personnel and protesters continued for a third straight day in a confrontation that looks set to further damage the credibility of the Egypt's ruling military regime.

headline: PNC Wins OK to Buy RBC's U.S. Banks
summary: The Federal Reserve late Monday said it has approved PNC Financial Services Group's plan to acquire Royal Bank of Canada's U.S. retail-banking unit.

headline: ECB Warns of Risks
summary: Risks to stability of the euro zone's financial system have risen "substantially" in the second half of this year, to their worst level since the collapse of Lehman in 2008, the ECB said.

headline: Rivals Try to Gain on Slowing Gingrich
summary: A two-week barrage of attack ads on television and radio appears to be damping enthusiasm for Newt Gingrich in Iowa. That has created an opening for other candidates to leapfrog the ex-House speaker.

headline: Traders Wager on Home Depot and Norfolk
summary: The options market was alive with "put" sellers Monday, as traders bet shares of Home Depot Inc. and Norfolk Southern Corp. can each hold strong 2011 gains into early next year.

headline: Business Owner's Bankruptcy Disclosed to Supreme Court
summary: An NFIB lawyer has notified the court of the recent bankruptcy of a key plaintiff in its high-profile challenge to the Obama administration's health-care overhaul.

headline: Economic Health of Pyongyang a Concern
summary: Kim left his country with an entrenched and repressive economic system whose collapse would bring a steep price to its neighbors.

headline: William Lyon Homes Enters Bankruptcy
summary: Homebuilding company William Lyon Homes filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Monday with plans to slash its debt by about $180 million.

headline: Euro Falls Below $1.30 Mark
summary: he threat of euro-zone sovereign credit downgrades weakened the euro Monday, as fears of skyrocketing European borrowing costs counterbalanced efforts by the 17-nation currency bloc to stabilize its debt crisis.

headline: Nasdaq Pushes Into Machine-Readable News
summary: The stock-exchange operator agreed to buy RapiData, in a push into the business of supplying economic news in tidbits that are digestable by trading algorithms.

headline: Photos of the Day: Dec. 19
summary: In today's photos, an elephant gets a bath in Sri Lanka, police officers attend a comrade's funeral on Long Island, a historical institute's books are destroyed in Egypt, and more.

headline: Danske Bank Names New CEO
summary: Danske Bank named board chairman Eivind Kolding as its new chief executive from Feb. 15 2012, giving him a broad mandate for change as the bank strives to ramp up profitability.

headline: Gold, Silver Appear Set to Shine in '12
summary: Analysts are predicting that gold and silver will make solid gains in 2012 as both move back into favor with investors as alternative stores of value.

headline: Caterpillar Continues Sales Growth Streak
summary: Caterpillar Inc. said Monday that global retail sales of its construction and mining machinery rose 30% in the three months to the end of November, as growth continued to slow in Latin America, offsetting strong sales expansion in North America.

headline: Importers Hamstrung in Argentina
summary: Argentina's government is now using import substitution policies to turn the South American nation into one of the world's most protectionist countries.

headline: Draghi Says Break-Up Speculation 'Morbid'
summary: The existence of the euro zone is "irreversible" and speculation about its breakup is "morbid," ECB President Mario Draghi said.

headline: Deutsche Ex-CEO Settles Case
summary: A German court said it would drop criminal fraud charges against former Deutsche Bank Chief Executive Rolf Breuer as part of a $457,000 settlement connected to the 2002 bankruptcy of media company Kirch Group.

headline: A Dictator Steeped in Myth
summary: Kim Jong Il, the leader of North Korea for nearly two decades, wasn't often seen and wasn't once heard by the outside world.

headline: JV to Buy Japan Property
summary: Global Logistic Properties, majority owned by Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, and sovereign wealth fund China Investment Corp. are jointly buying 15 logistic properties in one of the biggest property deals in Japan.

headline: FDA Restricts Use of Multaq
summary: Sanofi heart-rhythm drug Multaq, which has been linked to an increased risk of death among some groups of patients.

headline: Cnooc Shuts Platforms After Leak
summary: The Chinese state-owned energy giant said production on two platforms at the Zhuhai Hengqin gas-processing terminal has stopped after a leak was discovered in an underwater connecting pipeline.

headline: European Stocks End Nearly Flat
summary: European stock markets fell from highs to finish near flat to lower, with investors cautious after comments made by ECB President Mario Draghi on the state of the European economy, together with general nervousness about the outcome of a conference call of euro-zone ministers.

headline: Hahm Chaibong: Pyongyang's Succession Drama
summary: North Korea's long-suffering people will have to continue their "arduous march."

headline: Eldorado Gold Buys European Goldfields
summary: Eldorado Gold said it agreed to a cash-and-shares deal to buy European Goldfields, creating a gold producer with a market value of about C$11 billion.

headline: European Goldfields Deserves More Glitter
summary: Vancouver-based Eldorado Gold Corp. has made a C$2.5 billion offer in shares and a small amount of cash for Toronto-listed European Goldfields. But investors should remember that gifts often have less sparkle when fully unwrapped.

headline: Remember, S&P Isn't the Only Ratings Firm
summary: It has never been the case that a single ratings firm's decisions would drive markets. Next year, investors might get caught in a storm of downgrades.

headline: Comings and Goings | lawblog@wsj.com
summary: Only about 5% of top law firms place women in the role of managing partner, according to the National Association of Women Lawyers.

headline: Asian Shares Fall
summary: Asian stock markets dropped, with South Korea's stock market and the won tumbling to multiweek lows on news of the North Korean leader's death. Japan's Nikkei fell 1.3%.

headline: Sino-Forest Forms Committee
summary: Sino-Forest said its board established a special restructuring committee tasked with reviewing the strategic options.

headline: Qantas, Engineers Resolve Dispute
summary: Qantas Airways has reached an deal with a union representing 1,600 engineers, ending a standoff that was partly the cause of Australia's national carrier temporarily grounding its fleet.

headline: Japan Allocates Money for Cleanup
summary: The government minister in charge of the crisis at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant said that Tokyo has allocated more than $12.8 billion for decontamination of the areas around the plant.

headline: BT to Sue Google
summary: U.K. telecommunications firm BT Group PLC said Monday that it is suing Google Inc. for alleged patent infringement, in the latest lawsuit against the Internet giant.

headline: Three Gorges Cites Edge in Bid
summary: China Three Gorges said it has a slight edge in bidding for the Portuguese government's sale of 21% in Energias de Portugal.

headline: Treasury Prices Fall Ahead of Last 2011 Auctions
summary: The Treasury is slated to sell $99 billion worth of U.S. government debt this week, starting with a $35 billion two-year note sale Monday afternoon. Prices were under modest pressure ahead of the sale.

headline: Samsung Files New Apple Claims
summary: In new claims filed against Apple in Germany, Samsung claims the iPhone maker infringed on patents involving emoticons among other things.

headline: Russia Probes IKEA for Bribery
summary: Russian authorities accused a Swedish manager at a troubled unit of IKEA of attempting to extort a bribe from a local businessman.

headline: Ocado Hit By Capacity Issues Again
summary: U.K. online grocer Ocado warned that full-year profits would come in below expectations as it continues to be hurt by capacity issues at its main distribution hub.

headline: India Set for Record Wheat Crop
summary: India is likely to harvest a record wheat crop in 2011-12, aided by favorable weather and higher acreage, Farm Minister Sharad Pawar said.

headline: India Shares End at 28-Month Low
summary: Indian shares closed at a 28-month low, tracking broad declines in regional bourses and as worries over teetering domestic growth kept most investors on the sidelines.

headline: India Steel Demand Likely to Grow 8%
summary: India's steel demand is expected to grow by 8% in the current financial year through March despite slowing sales in the first eight months, a senior government official said.

headline: Etihad To Increase Air Berlin Stake
summary: Etihad Airlines will pay about €72.9 million ($95 million)  to become the biggest shareholder in discount carrier Air Berlin, the German airline said.

headline: India's Most Googled, 2011
summary: A look at the people who topped Google searches in India this year, in pictures.

headline: Kingfisher Airlines to Join Oneworld Alliance on Feb. 10
summary: Kingfisher Airlines said it will join the Oneworld global airline alliance from Feb. 10, a move that will give it access to a wide international network.

headline: Euro-Zone Bond Markets Nervous
summary: Non-core euro-zone government bonds were little changed with the exception of Belgium, with market participants keeping a close watch for possible further moves by rating firms after a flurry of action late Friday.

headline: Offshore Yuan's Onshore Controls
summary: Hong Kong's offshore yuan bond market is billed as the only place where China's currency trades freely. In fact, it remains a prisoner of the state.

headline: U.K. to Implement ICB Reforms in Full
summary: The U.K. government will accept the findings of John Vickers' Independent Commission on Banking report "in full," Business Secretary Vince Cable said.

headline: India Sugar Output Rises 19%
summary: India's sugar output from the start of the marketing year on Oct. 1 to Dec. 15 rose about 19% to 4.58 million metric from 3.86 million tons a year earlier due to higher crushing in major growing regions, the Indian Sugar Mills Association said.

headline: Deadly Storm Hits Philippines
summary: Rescue workers raced to find more than 800 people missing in the southern Philippines on Sunday after a series of flash floods killed more than 650 people, burying many in landslides and sweeping others out to sea.

headline: The Rubin Museum Gets Comical
summary: From Buddha to Bugs Bunny, a new exhibit at the Rubin Museum illuminates the long, unusual relationship between the South Asian region and the art of comic books.

headline: 'A Sabbatical? Me?'
summary: Yes, you. Taking a break from work might be easier than you think. Some employers even encourage employee sabbaticals as a way to recharge batteries.

headline: Performance Reviews Lose Steam
summary: It's that time of year again: Many workers and managers are preparing for the dreaded performance review. While most companies continue to do them, a few are scrapping the practice altogether.

headline: Need for Efficiency in China's Banks
summary: Shenzhen Development Bank President Richard Jackson Beijing's measures to slow credit growth will check the proliferation of nonperforming loans, but they come with risks in the long run.

headline: Dividend Stocks Become the Heroes
summary: U.S. stocks that pay high dividends, often derided as stodgy, are outdoing their lower-paying cousins.

headline: India's Slowdown Tarnishes Gold
summary: India's economy is looking decidedly less flashy these days, and the resulting drop in the value of its currency is making it expensive for locals to indulge their taste for bling.

headline: Palma Palace Penthouse
summary: This two-bedroom penthouse is one of three apartments that have been created from a 400-year-old palace in the old town of Palma de Mallorca.

headline: Olympus Warned By Big Investors
summary: Two big investors in Olympus lashed out at management's ideas about how to restore the company to health, saying they might challenge any attempt by the current board to keep their jobs.

headline: Paying Taxes on IRAs
summary: Karen Damato answers readers' questions on the tax implications of IRA distributions, Social Security survivor benefits and helping grandkids save

headline: Rule Change Would Shift Loan-Loss Accounting
summary: The new standard may require banks to book some loan losses more quickly.

headline: A Too-Familiar December Letdown
summary: The Giants didn't bring it down to the final minute this time. They didn't leave their fans on the edges of their seats, and Tom Coughlin's cardiac kids didn't put together some wild comeback.

headline: AMR Pensions Stir Debate
summary: The director of the U.S. pension guaranty agency assailed comments by AMR's lead bankruptcy lawyer suggesting the airline might terminate its underfunded employee pension plans.

headline: Rex Grossman Somehow Dismantles the Giants Again
summary: The Redskins quarterback wasn't at his best Sunday, but he didn't have to be.

headline: Philippine Floods Kill Hundreds
summary: Rescue workers raced to find more than 800 people missing in the southern Philippines after a series of flash floods killed more than 650 people, burying many in landslides and sweeping others out to sea.

headline: Bird's-Eye View, of Birders
summary: One of my wishes has always been to see a Rufous Hummingbird at our feeder. The Rufous is a rare but regular visitor. It was first spotted Wednesday near the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: Kodak Rescue Hits Hurdles
summary: Eastman Kodak is running into hurdles trying to sell some of its patents or borrow more money, as the film giant scrambles to raise cash.

headline: Laying Down the Law on Vacation Homes
summary: People who have second homes in desirable locales can find themselves overrun with family and friends. Readers give their advice on how to deal with requests to visit while retaining your friends—most of them, anyway—and your sanity.

headline: Blood, Gore and the Folly of 'Sustainable Capitalism'
summary: Al Gore and David Blood's "A Manifesto for Sustainable Capitalism" (op-ed, Dec. 14) reminds me of nothing so much as Enron Corporation.

headline: Indie Director Uses Marketing Skills
summary: Unlike some directors, "Pariah" writer-director Dee Rees has a background in corporate marketing, a skill set that came in handy while making her first feature film.

headline: Cellphone Carriers Keep Low Profile
summary: Watchdogs are pushing to ban cellphone calls by drivers. But carriers, caught between profits and safety, are keeping a low profile.

headline: Do the Rangers Have Stanley Cup Pedigree?
summary: They hit hard and have a great goalie in Henrik Lundqvist, but scoring has been anemic; Following the Bruins' blueprint

headline: Lucy Was Great, but Betty Is Still at It
summary: Terry Teachout's column ("The More Things on the Small Screen Change...," Sightings, Dec. 9) on the 60th year of truly national TV broadcasts neglected one present-day link to 1951. Betty White, nominated for an Emmy in 1951, is appearing in "It's Hot in Cleveland" in 2011. Lucy had a phenominal impact, but Betty is still punching!

headline: Battling the Blues
summary: Growing number of tools are available to help individuals fight depression. And more insurance help is on the way.

headline: Hockey Heats Up in Tiny Village With Israel's Only Big Rink
summary: A village of less than 2,000 residents has become a hot destination for many of the million-plus Russian immigrants to Israel. The draw: Israel's only regulation hockey rink.

headline: O'Grady: Peru's Humala Passes His First Test
summary: By lifting a blockade of a copper mine, Peru's President Ollanta Humala upholds the rule of law and sends a strong positive signal to foreign investors.

headline: Muted Volume Breaks Up Holiday Party
summary: Don't blame Santa for lackluster trading. The reasons go deeper than the holidays.

headline: The Daqduq Disgrace
summary: Obama releases a terrorist rather than send him to Gitmo.

headline: Handyman Charged in Arson Death
summary: A 47-year-old handyman was arrested Sunday in connection with the brutal burning death of an elderly Brooklyn woman who was doused with flammable liquid and set ablaze in the elevator of her apartment building.

headline: Brookdale Hospital Faces Scrutiny
summary: Health authorities have grown alarmed at mounting signs of disorder and danger to patients at a Brooklyn hospital already reeling from major financial problems and allegations of political corruption.

headline: Vancouver Renovation
summary: After renting out this home in Vancouver for two years, the owners decided to renovate and move in themselves. The two-bedroom unit has mahogany hardwood floors, a bar and a solarium.

headline: Out of Austria, Into Australia
summary: "Good Living Street" traces the history of a Viennese family that fled Hitler—but with a Klimt portrait in tow. Maxwell Carter reviews.

headline: Gingrich of Freddie Mac
summary: The Speaker's defense is hurting him as much as his $1.6 million payday.

headline: Gingrich's Worthy Brain Pulse
summary: An electromagnetic pulse attack is not a fanciful notion.

headline: Rahm Emanuel: Chicago's Plan to Match Education With Jobs
summary: AAR Corp., an aviation-parts manufacturer in the Chicago area, has 600 openings for welders and mechanics but can't find skilled workers to fill them.

headline: A Long Walk in England
summary: A reader's unforgettable walking tour of England's Cotswold Way, where beauty and history abound, along with first-rate inns and bed-and-breakfasts.

headline: Giving Love—and Life—Another Go
summary: How do you move on after the untimely death of a spouse? One woman traces a slow and deliberate journey that led her to rediscover life and love by finding a kindred spirit.

headline: Few Have Shed Payroll Like the Mets Have This Winter
summary: The Mets' payroll is shrinking to a degree almost unprecedented within the industry, at least in this millennium.

headline: The Best In…Staying Fit
summary: 'Ebikes' give cyclists a boost, and a guide to the link between higher Social Security payments and Medicare premiums.

headline: If Cross Bronx Is Jammed, Some Humor Never Hurts
summary: Former President Bill Clinton and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, were to speak the International Crisis Group, but the Cross Bronx Expressway wasn't cooperating.

headline: A Push to Turn 'For Sale' Into 'Sold'
summary: Some retirement communities are eager to help you sell your house, offering home-staging and repair services and no-interest bridge loans to help get you out of your space and into theirs.

headline: Chipotle Chief: Fix Immigration
summary: A crackdown earlier this year that found Chipotle Mexican Grill had hired hundreds of undocumented workers turned the company's leader into an unlikely champion of immigration reform.

headline: Fitch Seeks to Avoid Ratings Surprises
summary: The president of Fitch Ratings, Paul Taylor, said the credit-rating firm has sought to telegraph credit-rating changes to investors in order to limit the volatility that can be caused by such moves.

headline: Economy Takes a Licking, Keeps on Ticking
summary: Despite everything, the economy is ending the year on a high note. Maybe, despite everything, it will sustain it into next year.

headline: Editor's Note
summary: 'Voluntourism' combines two of the main themes of retirement—a desire to see the world and to make a difference in the lives of others.

headline: House Balks at Payroll Tax Deal
summary: Boehner ruled out approval of a Senate deal to extend the payroll-tax cut by two months after rank-and-file House Republicans rebelled.

headline: Knicks to Sign Davis, Battling a Back Injury
summary: Plus, the Giants' Devin Thomas was taken off the field on a stretcher; he later tweets that his injury seems to be just a stinger

headline: In 2012, Slow Return to European Stocks
summary: While 2012 is likely to start off bumpy, many analysts say equities are likely to be back in favor with investors before the year is out.

headline: The Best In…Financing Your Future
summary: How to recognize red flags for investment fraud, getting up to speed on Social Security.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: Europeans Stash Money Elsewhere
summary: Southern European investors are increasingly stashing their wealth in currencies, real estate and investment products outside the euro zone.

headline: North Korean Leader Kim Jong Il Is Dead
summary: Kim Jong Il, the dictator who used fear and isolation to maintain power in North Korea and his nuclear weapons to menace his neighbors and threaten the U.S., has died. State TV said the youngest of his three sons will succeed him.

headline: Shale's Growing Bounty
summary: The same drilling technologies that have unlocked vast amounts of crude and natural gas from shale formations are also reaping large stores of ethane, propane and butane, known as natural-gas liquids.

headline: Voters to Read Recovery Signs
summary: After more than two years of frustrating fits and starts, the U.S. economy shows modest signs of picking up, raising the question of whether such improvements could be lasting or significant enough to affect the 2012 campaign debate.

headline: Lots of Uncertainty in IPO Forecast
summary: The U.S. IPO market has entered its annual winter hibernation until mid-January, which means that investors and bankers have about a month to ponder: What will 2012 bring?

headline: Films Continue Slow Streak
summary: Following the movie industry's lowest-grossing weekend of the year last week, this weekend's new wide-release franchise films failed to match their previous installments, continuing a domestic box-office slump.

headline: The Law Misses Rogue Prosecutors
summary: I fully agree with the sentiments expressed in Jim Morhard's "Are Prosecutors Above the Law?" (op-ed, Dec. 3) about the dismissed conviction of former Alaska Sen. Ted Stevens.

headline: Solyndra Does Europe
summary: Germany's solar power industry is the latest to flop as subsidies ebb.

headline: Chomping Down on Buffalo Wild's Prospects
summary: Late to the fiesta with Chipotle Mexican Grill? There's still time to load up on another spicy growth stock: Buffalo Wild Wings.

headline: Spain Awaits Austerity Steps
summary: Spain's Prime Minister-elect Mariano Rajoy is expected to use his inauguration speech to rally support for his program of austerity.

headline: U.S., Allies Step Up Iran Embargo Talks
summary: The U.S. and key Arab states are intensifying talks on how to keep stability in the global energy markets, in a possible precursor to tighter sanctions against Iran.

headline: Migrant Ship Sinks Near Indonesia
summary: More than 200 asylum seekers were missing after their ship capsized on its way to Australia from Indonesia.

headline: For Todd Graham, It's One-and-Done
summary: Todd Graham established himself as the biggest nomad in recent college-football history.

headline: Asia's Allure Deepens for Law Firms
summary: A union between a leading Chinese law firm and a top Australian practice is causing a stir in a global legal industry long dominated by Western powers.

headline: Why U.S. Needs Newt Gingrich Now
summary: Peggy Noonan has captured the essence of what so many Americans are thinking about Newt Gingrich and the current plight of our country ("Gingrich Is Inspiring-and Disturbing," Declarations, Dec.10).

headline: Dear Book Lover: Happy Families
summary: A reader asks: Why aren't there more books about functional families?

headline: Cameron's Political Games Aren't Helping
summary: Much of the EU legislation the prime minister now says represents a threat to London reflects international agreements the U.K. not only supported but demanded.

headline: House Members Received VIP Loans
summary: Four current House members received loans through the controversial VIP program of Countrywide Financial, raising new questions about possible efforts to curry political influence by the onetime mortgage giant.

headline: Lenders Losing Battle of 'Basel'
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to embrace a new global framework that requires giant financial institutions to hold extra capital, a defeat for giant U.S. banks.

headline: Fewer Cards Could Damp Firm's Cheer
summary: American Greetings shareholders are hoping Santa delivers a good earnings report as the company looks to continue increasing revenue during its most important period of the year and amid heightened competition from the Web.

headline: On the Road Again…and Again
summary: Even in tough economic times, Americans can't resist the urge to travel—especially baby boomers. A look at the kind of trips they take and their most common destinations.

headline: GOP Rivals Diverge on Late Tactics in Iowa
summary: Newt Gingrich launched a broad attack on the judiciary, while Mitt Romney appeared to nudge his campaign toward the political center in their closing arguments to Iowa voters.

headline: A Clue to How Planets Formed
summary: NASA's fragile Dawn probe this week is skimming across the surface of the giant asteroid Vesta, prospecting for elements, in its closest approach to one of the solar system's most mysterious objects.

headline: Czech Playwright, Dissident Rose to Become President
summary: Vaclav Havel, the dissident playwright who wove theater into politics to peacefully bring down communism in Czechoslovakia, has died. He was 75.

headline: Mayor's Stolen Money in Deal
summary: The Queens political operative convicted of stealing from Mayor Michael Bloomberg has agreed to return $750,000 to the billionaire as a judge prepares to sentence him on Monday.

summary: Authorities are closely examining the account of a former Queens resident who legally purchased—but claims to have lost—the handgun that killed a New York City police officer last week.

headline: Crovitz: The Supreme Court and the Future of Journalism
summary: The FCC's obsolete cross-ownership rules hinder newspapers from competing in the digital world.

headline: John C. Goodman: Why Mandated Health Insurance Is Unfair
summary: There's an easier way to solve the 'free-rider' problem.

headline: Firms Bid on NATO Cyberwar
summary: NATO is focusing on the next front: cyberwar. The alliance is collecting bids from top defense companies including Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman to update and expand cybersecurity.

headline: Make Your Nest Egg Last Longer
summary: One adviser's plan for stretching your retirement savings and lowering your taxes involves an unconventional strategy: making simultaneous withdrawals from tax-deferred and taxable accounts—and possibly deferring Social Security payments.

headline: A Dictator Steeped in Myth
summary: North Korea's propaganda portraying a peerless leader rarely matched reality.

headline: Tebow-Mania Ends...For Now
summary: Tebow-Mania was unsustainable. Everyone knew that, even the most faithful supporters of the anomalous Denver Broncos quarterback, writes Jason Gay.

headline: A Bribe to Keep Pyongyang Quiet
summary: The big question is whether the North Korea will succeed in getting the U.S. and South Korea to bribe it to halt its nuclear program once again.

headline: Siemens Expands U.S. Push
summary: German engineering giant Siemens is adding heft to its campaign to win more business with the U.S. government by appointing former U.S. Gen. Stanley McChrystal to a supervisory role.

headline: Conflicting Risks Put Bonds In a Bind
summary: Investors are inclined to buy U.S. Treasurys because of the euro zone's burgeoning crisis, but that saddles them with yields that are unjustifiably low based on U.S. fundamentals.

headline: The Best In…The Good Life
summary: How to read your grandkids a bedtime story remotely, and neighbors-only social networks.

headline: Art of Home Building, Gingerbread Style
summary: Children were provided with a smorsgasbord of decorative material—Ladurée macarons, gumdrops, shoe-string licorice—with which to turn their shabby gingerbread houses into maisons en pain d'épice.
